Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Situation2: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Story: I stood behind the register, scanning items with practiced ease, when a woman approached, holding a sweater. She explained it was a gift from her mother, but she’d lost the receipt. Store policy was clear—no returns without proof of purchase. As a cashier, I was expected to enforce this rule, no exceptions. But as she spoke, I saw my own mother in her, recalling how my family always taught me to be compassionate and understanding, especially during the holidays. Our family traditions were built on kindness and helping others, values I was expected to uphold. Yet here I was, torn between the rigid expectations of my job and the softer, more forgiving values of my upbringing. My manager watched from across the floor, waiting to see if I’d follow procedure. The woman’s hopeful eyes met mine, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding something different from me.
